L1.brief_rationale: The structured system of communication used by humans; universally recognized as fundamental to human society and cognition.
A writing system where symbols represent individual sounds; universally familiar from everyday reading and writing.
A speech sound produced with an open vocal tract; universally taught in elementary education across languages.
A speech sound produced with partial or complete closure of the vocal tract; universally taught alongside vowels in elementary education.
A regional or social variety of a language; universally recognized from everyday experience with different accents and speech patterns.
The distinctive way of pronouncing a language associated with a region or social group; universally noticed in daily interactions.
The process of converting text or speech from one language to another; universally familiar from multilingual interactions and translated media.
A visual-gestural language system used by deaf communities; widely recognized as a complete natural language system.
A method of visually representing language through symbols; universally encountered through alphabets, syllabaries, and logographic systems.
The ability to use two or more languages; universally familiar as a common experience in multilingual societies worldwide.
A unit of pronunciation consisting of a vowel sound with optional surrounding consonants; universally understood from basic literacy education.
A group of languages descended from a common ancestor; widely known through major families like Indo-European, Sino-Tibetan, and Afro-Asiatic.
The first language a person learns from birth; universally understood as a fundamental aspect of personal identity.

L2.brief_rationale: The smallest unit of sound that distinguishes meaning in a language; a foundational concept in every introductory linguistics course.
The study of the internal structure and formation of words; one of the core subfields of linguistics taught in every introductory course.
The study of how language varies and changes in social contexts; a major subfield widely taught in undergraduate linguistics programs.
The study of how languages change over time; a core subfield examining sound changes, grammaticalization, and language divergence.
A standardized system of phonetic notation representing the sounds of spoken language; learned by every linguistics undergraduate.
The study of the origin and historical development of words; a standard topic in linguistics connecting to historical linguistics and lexicography.
The process by which humans learn to understand and produce language; a core topic studied in undergraduate linguistics and psychology.
A word adopted from one language into another; a standard concept in historical linguistics illustrating language contact and change.
Simplified contact languages (pidgins) that develop into full native languages (creoles); standard topics in sociolinguistics and language contact courses.
The variation of pitch in speech used to convey meaning, attitude, or grammatical structure; a core topic in phonology and prosody courses.
The study of how the mind processes and produces language; a major interdisciplinary subfield taught in undergraduate programs.
A language at risk of falling out of use as its speakers shift to other languages; a widely discussed topic in sociolinguistics and language documentation.
The study of how context contributes to meaning beyond literal semantics; a core subfield examining implicature, speech acts, and discourse.

L3.brief_rationale: The systematic study of sound patterns and their rules in languages; requires working knowledge of distinctive features, phonological rules, and representations.
The use of pitch to distinguish word meaning in tonal languages; requires working knowledge of tone systems across language families and their interaction with intonation.
A pair of words differing by only one phonological element that changes meaning; requires working knowledge of phonemic analysis and contrastive distribution.
A phonetic variant of a phoneme that does not change meaning; requires working knowledge of complementary distribution, free variation, and phonological analysis.
The classification of languages based on structural features like word order and morphological type; requires professional knowledge of cross-linguistic comparison methods.
The classification of languages by how they use morphemes (isolating, agglutinative, fusional, polysynthetic); requires working knowledge of morphological analysis across language types.
Systematic alterations in pronunciation that occur over time in a language; requires working knowledge of Grimm's Law, the Neogrammarian hypothesis, and phonological reconstruction.
The technique of comparing cognate forms across related languages to reconstruct their common ancestor; requires professional knowledge of historical linguistics methodology.
The practice of alternating between two or more languages in conversation; requires working knowledge of sociolinguistic theories of bilingual speech and its grammatical constraints.
Chomsky's hypothesis that the ability to acquire language is innate and governed by biological principles; requires working knowledge of the nativist-empiricist debate and its implications.
The theory that there is a biologically determined window for optimal language acquisition; requires working knowledge of Lenneberg's proposal and evidence from feral children and late learners.
The hypothesis that language structure influences thought and perception; requires working knowledge of the strong vs. weak versions and modern experimental evidence.

L4.brief_rationale: The minimal phonological properties (e.g., [+voice], [+nasal]) that distinguish phonemes; requires deep knowledge of Jakobson's and Chomsky-Halle's feature geometry and its role in phonological theory.
Goldsmith's framework representing phonological features on separate tiers linked by association lines; requires deep knowledge of tone representation, the OCP, and multi-tiered analysis.
The theory modeling stress patterns through hierarchical tree structures of strong and weak positions; requires expert knowledge of metrical feet, stress rules, and their interaction with morphology.
The layered organization of speech into units (mora, syllable, foot, prosodic word, phrase); requires deep knowledge of how prosodic domains condition phonological processes.

Prince and Smolensky's framework evaluating candidate outputs against ranked violable constraints; requires expert knowledge of constraint interaction, factorial typology, and the debate with rule-based phonology.
The process by which lexical items become grammatical markers over time; requires deep knowledge of unidirectionality, semantic bleaching, and its cross-linguistic patterns.

A grammatical pattern where the agent of a transitive verb is marked differently from both the intransitive subject and the patient; requires expert knowledge of split ergativity and its typological distribution.
Cases where the surface form of a word obscures the phonological rule that produced it; requires deep knowledge of rule ordering, counterfeeding, and counterbleeding interactions.

The study of how speech sounds are produced by the movement of articulators; requires deep knowledge of vocal tract anatomy, places and manners of articulation, and instrumental measurement techniques.

Wang's model of sound change spreading gradually through the lexicon word by word rather than applying uniformly; requires expert knowledge of its evidence, the Neogrammarian counterposition, and computational modeling approaches.

The phonological theory that voicing contrasts are better analyzed through laryngeal features ([spread glottis] vs. [voice]) rather than a single [voice] feature; requires specialist knowledge of cross-linguistic laryngeal typology.

The phenomenon of languages influencing each other through sustained interaction of their speakers; requires deep knowledge of substrate effects, areal features, mixed languages, and the mechanisms of structural borrowing.
